block.p: Israeli Parliament Moves To Call Early Elections Prime Minister Ehud Barak's government was thrown into tumult when a substantial majority of Parliament approved a bill to disperse and head toward new elections. Three of the six parties in Mr. Barak's broad coalition voted against him. Although the bill requires three more hearings to become law, it may break up the governing coalition and create a chaotic interlude as Mr. Barak seeks to prepare for final peace talks with the Palestinians.

Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright told Syrian and Egyptian officials in Cairo that the Clinton administration was willing to push again for peace talks between Damascus and Israel, but that its main goal was a settlement between Israel and the Palestinians.

U.S. Laser Weapon Test An antimissile laser destroyed an armed Katyusha rocket in flight during a test in New Mexico, the Army said. The development moves the laser a step closer to possible deployment along Israel's border with Lebanon, to defend Israel against guerrilla rocket attacks.
Debate Over Women's Rights The first lady of Egypt, Suzanne Mubarak, warned in an interview that confrontations over a bill of rights for women risk provoking a backlash that could impede progress.

Group Assails NATO on Kosovo Amnesty International said NATO violated international law in bombing Yugoslavia last year by hitting targets where civilians were sure to be killed. In a report that infuriated NATO leaders, the group said the bombing of the headquarters of Radio Television Serbia was ''a deliberate attack on a civilian object'' and amounted to a war crime.

Assassination in Sri Lanka A suicide bomber killed a cabinet minister and 20 other people at a fund-raising event for the families of slain soldiers in Ratmalana, an industrial suburb of the capital, Colombo. No group took responsibility.

G.O.P. to Soften Tone At Philadelphia Convention Advisers to Gov. George W. Bush say they are fashioning a Republican national convention that will emphasize policy over partisan vitriol and perhaps abandon the frequent practice of devoting one night to an attack on the opposition.
Gore in California Vice President Al Gore began a three-day West Coast campaign swing, making a fund-raising stop at a lunch with Native Americans.

Ten Commandments Judge Wins Judge Roy S. Moore, the Alabama jurist made famous by his defense of the Ten Commandments, won a convincing victory in Tuesday's Republican primary for chief justice of the State Supreme Court.

No Asylum for Cuban Athlete The Clinton administration forcibly repatriated a prominent player on Cuba's national baseball team, Andy Morales, who had tried to enter the United States by sea. Officials said Mr. Morales had failed to make the case that he faced persecution if returned to Cuba.

Disparity in Sentencing Cited Nearly twice as many blacks as whites are being imprisoned for drug offenses, even though studies have shown that there are five times more white drug users than black ones, Human Rights Watch said.

Arrest in '66 Rights Killing A white man, Ernest Henry Avants, 69, was arrested on federal charges that he killed a black man in 1966 in what officials said might have been a plot to lure the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to Mississippi so he could be assassinated.

Egyptair Crash Investigation American investigators, more certain than ever that a pilot deliberately caused the crash of Egyptair 990 as it left New York last October, are wrapping up their investigation and may approve their conclusions without a public hearing. The unusual approach is meant to avoid further damage to relations with Egypt.

Republican Senate Primary Is Unsettled in New Jersey With 99 percent of the vote counted, Congressman Robert D. Franks had 95,801 votes, or 35.4 percent, and State Senator William L. Gormley had 92,454, or 34.2 percent. But with absentee ballots uncounted, Mr. Gormley refused to concede.

Dorismond Meeting Sought Mayor Giuliani said that he twice tried to meet recently with the family of Patrick M. Dorismond, the unarmed black man shot dead in March by the police, to express belated sympathies. But he said he backed away because the family wanted its lawyer, Johnnie Cochran, present.
A Wedding Was the Motive The police said a man and a woman arrested in a botched bank robbery in Brooklyn said they needed money for their wedding on Saturday.

Reading Test Results Rise The Board of Education reported that students in New York City performed significantly better this year on a citywide reading test. Still, only 40.8 percent met the rigorous new curriculum standards on which they were being tested, compared with 35.5 percent last year.
Lakers Take Early Lead Los Angeles defeated the Indiana Pacers, 104-87, in Game 1 of the N.B.A. championship series.
Warning on Herb Supplement Doctors are reporting that a Chinese herb, Aristolochia fangchi, which has already been linked to kidney failure, may cause cancer as well.

Microsoft Breakup Ordered A federal judge ordered the breakup of Microsoft because it ''has proved untrustworthy in the past'' and did not appear to accept his ruling that it had broadly violated antitrust law.
William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, said he was looking forward to the next round, in a higher court.
AT&T Defers Higher Rates AT&T yielded to pressure from embarrassed federal regulators and angry consumer groups and said it would put off a rate increase.
Thomas W. Kelly The lieutenant general who was the voice and face of the Army for millions of Americans in daily news briefings during the war in the Persian Gulf was 67.
